natural problem: Ten 6-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that exactly three of the dice show a 1? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
natural solution: There are $\binom{10}{3}=120$ ways to select exactly three dice to roll 1's ones out of ten dice total. The probability of any one of these outcomes occurring is $\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7$ and they're all mutually exclusive cases, so the probability that one of them will occur (which is the probability that we're looking for) is $\binom{10}{3}\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7=\dfrac{120\cdot5^7\cdot1^3}{6^{10}}\approx \boxed{.155}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 10 3) * (1 / 6)^3 * (5 / 6)^7"
shows  "probability = 0.155"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten 6-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that exactly three of the dice show a 1? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .155
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{10}{3}=120$ ways to select exactly three dice to roll 1's ones out of ten dice total. The probability of any one of these outcomes occurring is $\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7$ and they're all mutually exclusive cases, so the probability that one of them will occur (which is the probability that we're looking for) is $\binom{10}{3}\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7=\dfrac{120\cdot5^7\cdot1^3}{6^{10}}\approx \boxed{.155}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 10 3) * (1 / 6)^3 * (5 / 6)^7"
shows  "probability = 0.155"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of getting exactly 3 successes in 10 Bernoulli trials with a success probability of $\frac{1}{6}$? The final answer is $0.155$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and p :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
and h1 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "binomial_coeff n 3 * (p ^ 3) * ((1 - p) ^ (n - 3)) = (approximate) .155"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten 6-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that exactly three of the dice show a 1? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .155
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{10}{3}=120$ ways to select exactly three dice to roll 1's ones out of ten dice total. The probability of any one of these outcomes occurring is $\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7$ and they're all mutually exclusive cases, so the probability that one of them will occur (which is the probability that we're looking for) is $\binom{10}{3}\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7=\dfrac{120\cdot5^7\cdot1^3}{6^{10}}\approx \boxed{.155}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and p :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
and h1 : "p = 1 / 6"
shows  "binomial_coeff n 3 * (p ^ 3) * ((1 - p) ^ (n - 3)) = (approximate) .155"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a binomial distribution with $n = 10$ trials and a probability of success $p = \frac{1}{6}$, find the probability of getting exactly 3 successes. The approximate final answer is $0.155$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 10 choose 3 * (1 / 6) powr 3 * (5 / 6) powr 7"
shows  "prob \<approx> 0.155"
a_2.formal solution:

theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 10 choose 3 * (1 / 6) powr 3 * (5 / 6) powr 7"

a_2.informal problem: What is the probability of getting exactly 3 successes in 10 trials, if the probability of success in each trial is $\frac{1}{6}$? The final answer is approximately $0.155$.

fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (binomial 10 3) * (1/6)^3 * (5/6)^7"
shows  "P = 0.155"

The probability of any one of these outcomes occurring is $\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7$ and they're all mutually exclusive cases, so the probability that one of them will occur (which is the probability that we're looking for) is $\binom{10}{3}\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7=\dfrac{120\cdot5^7\cdot1^3}{6^{10}}\approx \boxed{.155}$.

a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 10 coin tosses if the probability of getting a head is $\frac{1}{6}$ and the probability of getting a tail is $\frac{5}{6}$. The final answer is $0.155$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n p_prob :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
and h1 : "p_prob = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "binomial_coeff n 3 = 120"
shows  "real_of_float (Float 155 (-3)) = 120 * (p_prob ^ 3) * ((1 - p_prob) ^ 7)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Ten 6-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that exactly three of the dice show a 1? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is .155
 ### Proof
 There are $\binom{10}{3}=120$ ways to select exactly three dice to roll 1's ones out of ten dice total. The probability of any one of these outcomes occurring is $\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7$ and they're all mutually exclusive cases, so the probability that one of them will occur (which is the probability that we're looking for) is $\binom{10}{3}\left(\dfrac{1}{6}\right)^3\left(\dfrac{5}{6}\right)^7=\dfrac{120\cdot5^7\cdot1^3}{6^{10}}\approx \boxed{.155}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n p_prob :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
and h1 : "p_prob = 1 / 6"
and h2 : "binomial_coeff n 3 = 120"
shows  "real_of_float (Float 155 (-3)) = 120 * (p_prob ^ 3) * ((1 - p_prob) ^ 7)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled 10 times. What is the probability of rolling exactly 3 ones? Express your answer as a decimal. The final answer is 0.155.

fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "10 choose 3 = 120"
and h1 : "probability = 120 * (1/6)^3 * (5/6)^7"
